chat_history.content:
The 2010 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov for their groundbreaking experiments regarding the two-dimensional material graphene.

### Alma Maters of the Winners:
- **Andre Geim**: Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT)
- **Konstantin Novoselov**: Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT) and Radboud University Nijmegen in the Netherlands
chat_history.name: delegate

chat_history.content:
The Nobel Prize in Physics for the year 2011 was awarded to:

1. **Saul Perlmutter**
2. **Brian P. Schmidt**
3. **Adam G. Riess**

However, I was unable to retrieve the latest alma maters for these laureates from the search results. Here is some additional information that might help:

- **Saul Perlmutter** is a professor of physics at the University of California, Berkeley, and a senior scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.
- **Brian P. Schmidt** is the Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University.
- **Adam G. Riess** is a professor of astronomy and physics at Johns Hopkins University and a scientist at the Space Telescope Science Institute.

For the most accurate and up-to-date information, you may want to refer to their respective university profiles or official biographies.

chat_history.content:
The 2012 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded jointly to Serge Haroche and David J. Wineland for their groundbreaking experimental methods that enable measuring and manipulation of individual quantum systems.

### Latest Alma Maters:
- **Serge Haroche**:
  - **École Normale Supérieure (ENS)** in Paris (Undergraduate studies)
  - **University of Paris VI (Pierre and Marie Curie University)** (Ph.D.)

- **David J. Wineland**:
  - **University of California, Berkeley** (Bachelor's degree)
  - **Harvard University** (Ph.D.)

chat_history.content:
The Nobel Prize in Physics for the year 2013 was awarded to François Englert and Peter Higgs for their theoretical discovery of a mechanism that contributes to our understanding of the origin of mass of subatomic particles, which was confirmed through the discovery of the predicted fundamental particle by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at CERN's Large Hadron Collider.

Here are the latest alma maters of the 2013 Nobel Prize winners in Physics:

1. **François Englert**:
   - **Alma Mater**: Université Libre de Bruxelles (ULB), Belgium

2. **Peter Higgs**:
   - **Alma Mater**: King's College London, United Kingdom

These institutions are where the laureates completed their higher education and made significant contributions to their academic and research careers.

1. **Isamu Akasaki**: Kyoto University
2. **Hiroshi Amano**: Nagoya University
3. **Shuji Nakamura**: University of Tokushima

chat_history.content:
Here are the Nobel Prize winners in Physics from 2010 to 2014 along with their latest alma maters:

### 2010
- **Winners**: Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov
- **Awarded for**: Groundbreaking experiments regarding the two-dimensional material graphene.
- **Alma Maters**:
  - **Andre Geim**: Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT)
  - **Konstantin Novoselov**: Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT) and Radboud University Nijmegen in the Netherlands

### 2011
- **Winners**: Saul Perlmutter, Brian P. Schmidt, and Adam G. Riess
- **Awarded for**: The discovery of the accelerating expansion of the Universe through observations of distant supernovae.
- **Alma Maters**:
  - **Saul Perlmutter**: University of California, Berkeley (Professor of Physics)
  - **Brian P. Schmidt**: Australian National University (Vice-Chancellor)
  - **Adam G. Riess**: Johns Hopkins University (Professor of Astronomy and Physics) and Space Telescope Science Institute (Scientist)

### 2012
- **Winners**: Serge Haroche and David J. Wineland
- **Awarded for**: Groundbreaking experimental methods that enable measuring and manipulation of individual quantum systems.
- **Alma Maters**:
  - **Serge Haroche**: École Normale Supérieure (ENS) in Paris (Undergraduate), University of Paris VI (Pierre and Marie Curie University) (Ph.D.)
  - **David J. Wineland**: University of California, Berkeley (Bachelor's degree), Harvard University (Ph.D.)

### 2013
- **Winners**: François Englert and Peter Higgs
- **Awarded for**: Theoretical discovery of a mechanism that contributes to our understanding of the origin of mass of subatomic particles.
- **Alma Maters**:
  - **François Englert**: Université Libre de Bruxelles (ULB), Belgium
  - **Peter Higgs**: King's College London, United Kingdom

### 2014
- **Winners**: Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano, and Shuji Nakamura
- **Awarded for**: The invention of efficient blue light-emitting diodes which has enabled bright and energy-saving white light sources.
- **Alma Maters**:
  - **Isamu Akasaki**: Kyoto University
  - **Hiroshi Amano**: Nagoya University
  - **Shuji Nakamura**: University of Tokushima

The Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to 224 individuals as of 2023.[5] The first prize in physics was awarded in 1901 to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, of Germany, who received 150,782 SEK. John Bardeen is the only laureate to win the prize twice—in 1956 and 1972.


William Lawrence Bragg was the youngest Nobel laureate in physics; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25. He was also the youngest laureate for any Nobel prize until 2014 (when Malala Yousafzai won the Nobel Peace Prize at age 17).[6] The oldest Nobel Prize laureate in physics was Arthur Ashkin who was 96 years old when he was awarded the prize in 2018.[7]


Only five women have won the prize: Marie Curie (1903), Maria Goeppert-Mayer (1963), Donna Strickland (2018), Andrea Ghez (2020), and Anne L'Huillier (2023).[8] Before L'Huillier, each woman only ever received a quarter share of the prize, although Marie Curie did receive an unshared Nobel prize in chemistry in 1911. In 2023 L'Huillier received a one-third share.

The Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to 224 individuals as of 2023.[5] The first prize in physics was awarded in 1901 to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, of Germany, who received 150,782 SEK. John Bardeen is the only laureate to win the prize twice—in 1956 and 1972.


William Lawrence Bragg was the youngest Nobel laureate in physics; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25. He was also the youngest laureate for any Nobel prize until 2014 (when Malala Yousafzai won the Nobel Peace Prize at age 17).[6] The oldest Nobel Prize laureate in physics was Arthur Ashkin who was 96 years old when he was awarded the prize in 2018.[7]


Only five women have won the prize: Marie Curie (1903), Maria Goeppert-Mayer (1963), Donna Strickland (2018), Andrea Ghez (2020), and Anne L'Huillier (2023).[8] Before L'Huillier, each woman only ever received a quarter share of the prize, although Marie Curie did receive an unshared Nobel prize in chemistry in 1911. In 2023 L'Huillier received a one-third share.

<fragment>

The Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to 224 individuals as of 2023.[5] The first prize in physics was awarded in 1901 to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, of Germany, who received 150,782 SEK. John Bardeen is the only laureate to win the prize twice—in 1956 and 1972.


William Lawrence Bragg was the youngest Nobel laureate in physics; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25. He was also the youngest laureate for any Nobel prize until 2014 (when Malala Yousafzai won the Nobel Peace Prize at age 17).[6] The oldest Nobel Prize laureate in physics was Arthur Ashkin who was 96 years old when he was awarded the prize in 2018.[7]


Only five women have won the prize: Marie Curie (1903), Maria Goeppert-Mayer (1963), Donna Strickland (2018), Andrea Ghez (2020), and Anne L'Huillier (2023).[8] Before L'Huillier, each woman only ever received a quarter share of the prize, although Marie Curie did receive an unshared Nobel prize in chemistry in 1911. In 2023 L'Huillier received a one-third share.

chat_history.content:
The 2012 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded jointly to Serge Haroche and David J. Wineland for their groundbreaking experimental methods that enable measuring and manipulation of individual quantum systems. To find their latest alma maters, let's look up their educational backgrounds.

### Serge Haroche
Serge Haroche is a French physicist. His educational background includes:
- **École Normale Supérieure (ENS)** in Paris, where he completed his undergraduate studies.
- **University of Paris VI (Pierre and Marie Curie University)**, where he earned his Ph.D.

### David J. Wineland
David J. Wineland is an American physicist. His educational background includes:
- **University of California, Berkeley**, where he received his bachelor's degree.
- **Harvard University**, where he earned his Ph.D.

These institutions are the latest alma maters for the 2012 Nobel Prize winners in Physics.

<document>
<title>Nobel Prize in Physics</title>
<fragment>

The Nobel laureates are selected by the Nobel Committee for Physics, a Nobel Committee that consists of five members elected by The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. During the first stage that begins in September, a group of about 3,000 selected university professors, Nobel Laureates in Physics and Chemistry, and others are sent confidential nomination forms. The completed forms must arrive at the Nobel Committee by 31 January of the following year. The nominees are scrutinized and discussed by experts and are narrowed to approximately fifteen names. The committee submits a report with recommendations on the final candidates to the Academy, where, in the Physics Class, it is further discussed. The Academy then makes the final selection of the Laureates in Physics by a majority vote.[14]


</fragment>
<fragment>
One of the five Nobel Prizes established in 1895 by Alfred Nobel

For a list of laureates, see List of Nobel laureates in Physics.





Award


| Nobel Prize in Physics |
| --- |
| ![A golden medallion with an embossed image of a bearded man facing left in profile. To the left of the man is the text "ALFR•" then "NOBEL", and on the right, the text (smaller) "NAT•" then "MDCCCXXXIII" above, followed by (smaller) "OB•" then "MDCCCXCVI" below.](image) |
| Awarded for | Outstanding contributions for humankind in the field of physics |
| Location | Stockholm, Sweden |
| Presented by | Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences |
| Reward(s) | 11 million Swedish kronor (2023)[1] |
| First awarded | 1901 |
| Last awarded | 2023 |
| Most recently awarded to | Pierre Agostini, Ferenc Krausz, and Anne L'Huillier |
| Most awards | John Bardeen (2) |
| Website | nobelprize.org |
|

"Why it has become more difficult to predict Nobel Prize winners: A bibliometric analysis of nominees and winners of the chemistry and physics prizes (1901–2007)". *Scientometrics*. **82** (2): 401. arXiv:0808.2517. doi:10.1007/s11192-009-0035-9. S2CID 23293903.
18. **^** "A noble prize". *Nature Chemistry*. **1** (7): 509. 2009. Bibcode:2009NatCh...1..509.. doi:10.1038/nchem.372. PMID 21378920.

</fragment>
<fragment>

The committee and institution serving as the selection board for the prize typically announce the names of the laureates during the first week of October. The prize is then awarded at formal ceremonies held annually in Stockholm Concert Hall on 10 December, the anniversary of Nobel's death. The laureates receive a diploma, a medal and a document confirming the prize amount.[30]

![](image)Three Nobel Laureates in Physics. Front row L-R: Albert A. Michelson (1907 laureate), Albert Einstein (1921 laureate), and Robert A. Millikan (1923 laureate).
A maximum of three Nobel laureates and two different works may be selected for the Nobel Prize in Physics.[12] Compared with other Nobel Prizes, the nomination and selection process for the prize in physics is long and rigorous. This is a key reason why it has grown in importance over the years to become the most important prize in Physics.[13]

The rules for the Nobel Prize in Physics require that the significance of achievements being recognized has been "tested by time". In practice, that means that the lag between the discovery and the award is typically on the order of 20 years and can be much longer. For example, half of the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar for his work on stellar structure and evolution that was done during the 1930s. As a downside of this tested-by-time rule, not all scientists live long enough for their work to be recognized. Some important scientific discoveries are never considered for a prize, as the discoverers die by the time the impact of their work is appreciated.[17][18]



## Prizes[edit]


A Physics Nobel Prize laureate is awarded a gold medal, a diploma bearing a citation, and a sum of money.[19]



### Medals[edit]


Main article: Nobel Prize medal § Physics and Chemistry


</fragment>
<fragment>

![](image)Wilhelm Röntgen (1845–1923), the first recipient of the Nobel Prize in Physics
The **Nobel Prize in Physics** (Swedish: *Nobelpriset i fysik*) is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for humankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901, the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Physics is traditionally the first award presented in the Nobel Prize ceremony.


The prize consists of a medal along with a diploma and a certificate for the monetary award. The front side of the medal displays the same profile of Alfred Nobel depicted on the medals for Physics, Chemistry, and Literature.

The Nobel Prize in Physics for the year 2013 was awarded to François Englert and Peter Higgs for their theoretical discovery of a mechanism that contributes to our understanding of the origin of mass of subatomic particles, and which recently was confirmed through the discovery of the predicted fundamental particle, by the ATLAS and CMS experiments at CERN's Large Hadron Collider.

Here are the alma maters of the 2013 Nobel Prize winners in Physics:

1. **François Englert**:
   - **Alma Mater**: Université Libre de Bruxelles (ULB), Belgium

2. **Peter Higgs**:
   - **Alma Mater**: King's College London, United Kingdom

These institutions are where the laureates completed their higher education and contributed significantly to their academic and research careers.

The Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to 224 individuals as of 2023.[5] The first prize in physics was awarded in 1901 to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, of Germany, who received 150,782 SEK. John Bardeen is the only laureate to win the prize twice—in 1956 and 1972.


William Lawrence Bragg was the youngest Nobel laureate in physics; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25. He was also the youngest laureate for any Nobel prize until 2014 (when Malala Yousafzai won the Nobel Peace Prize at age 17).[6] The oldest Nobel Prize laureate in physics was Arthur Ashkin who was 96 years old when he was awarded the prize in 2018.[7]


Only five women have won the prize: Marie Curie (1903), Maria Goeppert-Mayer (1963), Donna Strickland (2018), Andrea Ghez (2020), and Anne L'Huillier (2023).[8] Before L'Huillier, each woman only ever received a quarter share of the prize, although Marie Curie did receive an unshared Nobel prize in chemistry in 1911. In 2023 L'Huillier received a one-third share.

<document>
<title>Nobel Prize in Physics</title>
<fragment>
13. **^** "The Nobel Prize Selection Process". Britannica Encyclopaedia. Archived from the original on 29 April 2015. Retrieved 4 May 2015.

"Why it has become more difficult to predict Nobel Prize winners: A bibliometric analysis of nominees and winners of the chemistry and physics prizes (1901–2007)". *Scientometrics*. **82** (2): 401. arXiv:0808.2517. doi:10.1007/s11192-009-0035-9. S2CID 23293903.
18. **^** "A noble prize". *Nature Chemistry*. **1** (7): 509. 2009. Bibcode:2009NatCh...1..509.. doi:10.1038/nchem.372. PMID 21378920.

</fragment>
<fragment>

The Nobel laureates are selected by the Nobel Committee for Physics, a Nobel Committee that consists of five members elected by The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. During the first stage that begins in September, a group of about 3,000 selected university professors, Nobel Laureates in Physics and Chemistry, and others are sent confidential nomination forms. The completed forms must arrive at the Nobel Committee by 31 January of the following year. The nominees are scrutinized and discussed by experts and are narrowed to approximately fifteen names. The committee submits a report with recommendations on the final candidates to the Academy, where, in the Physics Class, it is further discussed. The Academy then makes the final selection of the Laureates in Physics by a majority vote.[14]


</fragment>
<fragment>

The committee and institution serving as the selection board for the prize typically announce the names of the laureates during the first week of October. The prize is then awarded at formal ceremonies held annually in Stockholm Concert Hall on 10 December, the anniversary of Nobel's death. The laureates receive a diploma, a medal and a document confirming the prize amount.[30]

This is a key reason why it has grown in importance over the years to become the most important prize in Physics.[13]

<fragment>

![](image)Wilhelm Röntgen (1845–1923), the first recipient of the Nobel Prize in Physics
The **Nobel Prize in Physics** (Swedish: *Nobelpriset i fysik*) is a yearly award given by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for those who have made the most outstanding contributions for humankind in the field of physics. It is one of the five Nobel Prizes established by the will of Alfred Nobel in 1895 and awarded since 1901, the others being the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Nobel Prize in Literature, Nobel Peace Prize, and Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. Physics is traditionally the first award presented in the Nobel Prize ceremony.


The prize consists of a medal along with a diploma and a certificate for the monetary award. The front side of the medal displays the same profile of Alfred Nobel depicted on the medals for Physics, Chemistry, and Literature.


</fragment>
<fragment>

The rules for the Nobel Prize in Physics require that the significance of achievements being recognized has been "tested by time". In practice, that means that the lag between the discovery and the award is typically on the order of 20 years and can be much longer. For example, half of the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar for his work on stellar structure and evolution that was done during the 1930s. As a downside of this tested-by-time rule, not all scientists live long enough for their work to be recognized. Some important scientific discoveries are never considered for a prize, as the discoverers die by the time the impact of their work is appreciated.[17][18]



## Prizes[edit]


A Physics Nobel Prize laureate is awarded a gold medal, a diploma bearing a citation, and a sum of money.[19]



### Medals[edit]


Main article: Nobel Prize medal § Physics and Chemistry

chat_history.content:
### Andre Geim
Andre Geim completed his education at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT), where he earned his PhD.

### Konstantin Novoselov
Konstantin Novoselov completed his education at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT) and later earned his PhD from Radboud University Nijmegen in the Netherlands.

Both Nobel laureates have strong educational backgrounds from prestigious institutions, contributing to their groundbreaking work on graphene.

Ioannidis *et al.* reported that half of the Nobel Prize for science awarded between 1995 and 2017 are clustered in few disciplines. Particle physics (14%), atomic physics (10.9%), and 3 non-physics disciplines are dominating the prize in recent decades. And then semiconductor physics and magnetics are the next most honoured physics disciplines.[18]

<fragment>

The Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to 224 individuals as of 2023.[5] The first prize in physics was awarded in 1901 to Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen, of Germany, who received 150,782 SEK. John Bardeen is the only laureate to win the prize twice—in 1956 and 1972.


William Lawrence Bragg was the youngest Nobel laureate in physics; he won the prize in 1915 at the age of 25. He was also the youngest laureate for any Nobel prize until 2014 (when Malala Yousafzai won the Nobel Peace Prize at age 17).[6] The oldest Nobel Prize laureate in physics was Arthur Ashkin who was 96 years old when he was awarded the prize in 2018.[7]


Only five women have won the prize: Marie Curie (1903), Maria Goeppert-Mayer (1963), Donna Strickland (2018), Andrea Ghez (2020), and Anne L'Huillier (2023).[8] Before L'Huillier, each woman only ever received a quarter share of the prize, although Marie Curie did receive an unshared Nobel prize in chemistry in 1911. In 2023 L'Huillier received a one-third share.

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
The 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano, and Shuji Nakamura for their work on blue light-emitting diodes (LEDs).

Here are the latest alma maters of the winners:

1. **Isamu Akasaki**:
   - **Alma Mater**: Kyoto University

2. **Hiroshi Amano**:
   - **Alma Mater**: Nagoya University

3. **Shuji Nakamura**:
   - **Alma Mater**: University of Tokushima

These institutions were where they completed their higher education and conducted significant parts of their research.

functions.name: delegate
functions.desc:
Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

instructions.description: Detailed instructions on what your helper should do to help you.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
